story:
The last five years have seen Dilijan National Park grow into Armenia’s premier hiking destination – but there's still no dedicated place for the trail community to meet, stay and explore its natural beauty. That's where Dilijan Hikers Hostel comes in!

Set in the heart of Dilijan's historic quarter, Dilijan Hikers Hostel will be a haven for hikers of all levels of experience to explore the region by foot. But we won't just provide a comfortable bed: this will also be a place to access detailed information about the national park, share experiences with new friends, and – perhaps most importantly – know that each stay is helping support the trails that bring hikers to Dilijan in the first place.

So help us open our doors and create a gateway to Dilijan National Park! With your contributions, we'll be able to start welcoming local and international hikers this summer, promoting and maintaining the trails that lie within its beautiful ecosystem, and cultivating a community of environmentally conscious travelers.

And whether you just want to support our cause, or you're actively planning a trip to Dilijan, there's a reward available for your donation. Keep reading to find out more...

Our Story 

In the spring of 2020, the original planned opening of Dilijan Hikers Hostel was abruptly halted due to the outbreak of Covid-19 and the complete shutdown of the travel industry. It was in the aftermath of this very difficult year that a pair of repatriates found themselves ready to embrace the challenge of helping rebuild Armenia's struggling ecotourism industry. Lusine, founder of Cleodigital, and Ani, a Boston-based legal consultant, reunited in Yerevan for the first time in many years, having both grown up in the same city. A shared love for the natural beauty of the Caucasus and a desire to contribute to our native country led us to the opportunity to resurrect Dilijan Hikers Hostel.

Our goal for the coming months is to complete the building’s major renovations, play host to a small army of volunteers who will furnish and decorate the place, and launch a successful hostel, with the long-term aim of establishing a social enterprise model that can be replicated throughout the trail network in Armenia and beyond.

Dilijan In Detail

Armenia is fast emerging as a hiking destination for intrepid travelers want to explore the multitude of landscapes found in this one small country, and Dilijan National Park is at the heart of its growing trail network. Its forested landscape offers hikers the chance to meander through alpine forests that lead to picturesque lakes, discovering ancient monasteries en route to majestic views from rugged clifftops.

Recognizing the region’s potential to grow into one of the world’s best hiking destinations, work began on the Transcaucasian Trail in 2016. As a result, a 200km network of trails in Dilijan National Park was revamped over the following years to serve the ever-growing number of adventure travelers. At the heart of ths trail network is Dilijan itself – a culturally and architecturally unique town with an emerging gastronomic scene, and the obvious hub for visitors to explore the many trails suited for hikers of all skill levels.  

We've noticed, however, that there is still no dedicated place in Dilijan for hikers to congregate, have their questions about the trail network answered, and get inspired to explore the hidden wonders of Dilijan National Park. Dilijan Hikers Hostel will bridge this gap between accommodation and information, bringing together the growing community of nature seekers in Armenia.

 

 

Going Beyond Just Business-As-Usual

Dilijan Hikers Hostel will be more than just another small accommodation provider competing for bed sales. Directly bound to the success of our venture is the quality of the trail experience that helps make Dilijan a premier hiking destination, as well as the multi-faceted service industry that surrounds it.

Our business model will both incorporate the local community through employment opportunities and support the organizations involved in rebuilding and maintaining Dilijan National Park's trail network. In other words, our success will be shared with everyone – with the goal of giving back as much as we get. Here's how:

Local Employment Opportunities: Running our hostel will require hands-on help, from cleaning to cooking for larger groups, laundry service, and building maintenance. All the renovation work, materials purchased and furniture made will happen within the local community. Our guests will also help support local employment by booking transportation services, hiring local hiking guides, renting equipment, and more. 

Supporting Local Businesses: We want to help our guests experience everything unique that Dilijan has to offer. We'll work together with restaurants, museums, cafes, and other services offered throughout the town to make this happen. This combination of local culture and natural wonders is a key part of what makes a visit to Dilijan so memorable.

Supporting Ecotourism & Conservation: From designing new trails to renovating and maintaining existing routes to keep them accessible and safe, a community of dedicated people and organisations continues to improve the trail experience for visitors of the park. We won't just be local advocates for their goals but give our guests the opportunity to support them – perhaps even volunteering to help – and making our hostel available as a headquarters for those involved with trail building and maintenance.  

Among the many organizations whose enormous efforts we will continue to support, here are some of the most prominent:

  • The Transcaucasian Trail (TCT): The TCT is establishing a world-class long-distance hiking trail more than 3,000km in length, following the Greater and Lesser Caucasus Mountains and connecting roughly two dozen national parks and protected areas in the region, including Dilijan National Park. Visit https://transcaucasiantrail.org
  • HIKEArmenia: HIKEArmenia is a non-profit NGO developing hiking infrastructure in Armenia and sharing the country's trail potential with the world, and has supported the development of Dilijan National Park's trail network for several years. Visit https://hikearmenia.org
  • Trails for Change (TFC): Born around the campfire during a volunteer trail-building camp in Dilijan National Park, the mission of TFC is to design, build and maintain a network of trails that span all of Armenia. Visit https://www.trailsforchangengo.org

 

Here's How Dilijan Hiker's Hostel Stands Out

Location: With our location being right in the heart of picturesque Old Dilijan, a traveler couldn’t ask for anything better. Access to trails is only footsteps away, as well as transportation to get you further into the park. Beyond getting outdoors, we urge you to experience a taste of Dilijan’s local culture through its restaurants, cafes, and markets – all within just a few minutes' walk.

Knowledgeable Staff: The Dilijan Hikers Hostel team will be there to welcome you and help you get the most out of your experience. In addition to providing maps, sharing knowledge and advice, and helping you prepare for your time in Dilijan National Park, we’ll be there to recommend which trails you and your group will enjoy the most, no matter what your fitness or skill level.

Clean and Safe Facilities: A safe and clean environment is our top priority – not just taking extra precautions during the Covid-19 pandemic but ensuring a well-maintained communal living environment at all times. Peace of mind for our visitors is of utmost importance and we’ll be working hard to demonstrate this. 

Supporting Local Trails: Dilijan Hikers Hostel will directly support the local trail network by hosting volunteer trail maintenance events, providing tools and facilities, and donating a portion of its profits back to the Transcaucasian Trail. We will be the first of many affiliated businesses that will help ensure the future of TCT. 

Promote Environmental Awareness: We want to be a part of maintaining the health of Dilijan’s ecosystem. Providing educational material to guests and highlighting the fragility of our surroundings will ensure that we all do our part in fostering a community of low-impact travelers. 

Having Fun! What’s better than coming back from a long hike, taking a hot shower, and opening a bottle of beer with new friends? The hostel will be designed from the ground up as a communal environment where guests can share experiences and make new and unforgettable memories.

Why Build Dilijan Hikers Hostel Now?

The year of 2020 will go down in history for turning people's plans upside down and inside out – but we've all learned to adapt! One of the effects is that we anticipate a much higher number of local travelers in 2021. As and when the pandemic draws to an end, we expect to see the international community coming back to Armenia as more and more people resume their travel plans. We will be taking all the necessary steps to ensure the safety of our guests, while at the same time nurturing our hostel's potential for the future.

Alright, Let's Talk Money. Where Will The Funds Go?

We are lucky enough to have been donated the use of an old townhouse in the heart of Dilijan which will be converted into a hostel – but it needs some work! With one big effort this spring, we’ll be able to outfit the building to the high standards of comfort, safety, and sanitation so often lacking in Armenia. This project will require a couple of major renovation projects, along with a lot of volunteer help, and of course the tools and materials for DIY projects and furnishings. We also want ensure we can pay our local staff a fair salary from Day One.

Here’s a breakdown of what needs to happen between now and opening day:

In a bit more detail:

Reception & Information Area: We want guests of our hostel to have access to extensive information about the trail network and the local area so they feel their time in Dilijan has been well spent. A number of DIY projects will be involved in creating a communal reception and information area for this to happen.

Outdoor Roofing: It sounds like a big job...and it is! A new roof over our terrace and entranceway is certainly something we'll be hiring local contractors to build, but when finished, will guarantee that our guests can enjoy cooking, dining and hanging out in the fresh mountain air – even when it's raining!

Outdoor Kitchen & Dining: Hikers love being outdoors, and in the time of Covid-19 it's best for safety too. So we'll provide a full outdoor kitchen and BBQ area to both bring people together and keep everyone safe. Summer in Dilijan is best spent with mornings soaking up the sun, days out on the trail, and evenings by a campfire, and that's exactly what we'll provide.

Security: Peace-of-mind is essential in any communal environment. So we'll be installing security cameras, building private lockers, and encolsing the property with a secure gate and fence. At the same time we'll create a keyless entry system for our guests.

Pavements: You know what’s not fun after tramping through the dirt all day? More dirt. A hikers' hostel needs to be the clean end-point of a long day on the trails. We’ve redesigned the access routes to our hostel with this in mind, and now we need the funds to build it.

Plumbing: After a day out on the trails, there’s nothing you’re looking more forward to than a hot shower – and nothing worse than it running cold when someone turns on the tap in the kitchen! We'll be redesigning the building's plumbing to make sure this doesn't happen, and that everyone has hot and cold water when and where they need it.

Electrical Installation: Old buildings in Armenia have often been wired... well, questionably. At the same time, today's travelers often pack a huge array of power-hungry devices. So we'll be outfitting the building with a brand new electrical system – critical for safety, and with the convenience of our guests a top priority.

Large Appliances: Especially on a multi-day hike, laundry is a critical service for any hiker stopping over in a town like Dilijan. We'll be procuring a new and efficient washing machine that's up to this arduous task, along with a separate drying machine for rainy days (and there are plenty of those in Dilijan!).

Air Conditioning & Ventilation: As well as being essential for comfort in the summer months, good ventilation is critical for hygiene in any communal living space.

Business Operations: There's also plenty to do behind-the-scenes, including creating a booking system, website development, advertising, overhead costs, and salaries for our local staff. The complete guest experience is vital to the success of this venture, and we want to make it smooth and effortless.

Emergency Funds: This is a big project with lots of variables, and that means having a contingency fund for when things don't quite go to plan. We've built a buffer into our budget so we're confident in being able to weather any sudden storms during our critical first year of operations.

Perks for Donors

Dilijan Hikers Hostel thanks you ahead of time for the contributions you make. Despite the limitations of this past year, we are expecting a high number of local tourists and want to ensure they have a clean and comfortable place to seek shelter in. Our commitment to serving our local community will be the foundation for this ever-growing project and we invite you to be a part of our journey! 

Pre-Book Your Stay: Summer is around the corner and soon we'll be rushing outdoors and planning some fun trips. Here's your chance to book your stay at Dilijan Hikers Hostel ahead of time and have a guaranteed spot available for you when you arrive in Dilijan. Whether you're pre-booking one night or more, alone or with friends, this is a great opportunity to plan ahead, receive lots of add-ons and a special thank you from us. 

Sponsoring the Local Community: A core objective for creating Dilijan Hikers Hostel is giving back to the trail network that brings us our guests! We invite you to help us by sponsoring trail clean-up days, trail-building events, and inviting local hikers to join us in exploring Dilijan National Park. Your efforts won't go unnoticed and you can expect to receive a special thank you from us and everyone who benefitted from your donation.

Merchandise: In addition to handwritten thank-you cards, We'll also be rewarding our donors with beautifully crafted maps of Dilijan National Park. Check them out here: https://cartisan.org/product/dilijan-national-p....

There's other TCT and Dilijan National Park merchandise available too – something, we hope, for everyone.
story_txt:
The last five years have seen Dilijan National Park grow into Armenia’s premier hiking destination – but there's still no dedicated place for the trail community to meet, stay and explore its natural beauty. That's where Dilijan Hikers Hostel comes in!Set in the heart of Dilijan's historic quarter, Dilijan Hikers Hostel will be a haven for hikers of all levels of experience to explore the region by foot. But we won't just provide a comfortable bed: this will also be a place to access detailed information about the national park, share experiences with new friends, and – perhaps most importantly – know that each stay is helping support the trails that bring hikers to Dilijan in the first place.So help us open our doors and create a gateway to Dilijan National Park! With your contributions, we'll be able to start welcoming local and international hikers this summer, promoting and maintaining the trails that lie within its beautiful ecosystem, and cultivating a community of environmentally conscious travelers.And whether you just want to support our cause, or you're actively planning a trip to Dilijan, there's a reward available for your donation. Keep reading to find out more...Our Story In the spring of 2020, the original planned opening of Dilijan Hikers Hostel was abruptly halted due to the outbreak of Covid-19 and the complete shutdown of the travel industry. It was in the aftermath of this very difficult year that a pair of repatriates found themselves ready to embrace the challenge of helping rebuild Armenia's struggling ecotourism industry. Lusine, founder of Cleodigital, and Ani, a Boston-based legal consultant, reunited in Yerevan for the first time in many years, having both grown up in the same city. A shared love for the natural beauty of the Caucasus and a desire to contribute to our native country led us to the opportunity to resurrect Dilijan Hikers Hostel.Our goal for the coming months is to complete the building’s major renovations, play host to a small army of volunteers who will furnish and decorate the place, and launch a successful hostel, with the long-term aim of establishing a social enterprise model that can be replicated throughout the trail network in Armenia and beyond.Dilijan In DetailArmenia is fast emerging as a hiking destination for intrepid travelers want to explore the multitude of landscapes found in this one small country, and Dilijan National Park is at the heart of its growing trail network. Its forested landscape offers hikers the chance to meander through alpine forests that lead to picturesque lakes, discovering ancient monasteries en route to majestic views from rugged clifftops.Recognizing the region’s potential to grow into one of the world’s best hiking destinations, work began on the Transcaucasian Trail in 2016. As a result, a 200km network of trails in Dilijan National Park was revamped over the following years to serve the ever-growing number of adventure travelers. At the heart of ths trail network is Dilijan itself – a culturally and architecturally unique town with an emerging gastronomic scene, and the obvious hub for visitors to explore the many trails suited for hikers of all skill levels.  We've noticed, however, that there is still no dedicated place in Dilijan for hikers to congregate, have their questions about the trail network answered, and get inspired to explore the hidden wonders of Dilijan National Park. Dilijan Hikers Hostel will bridge this gap between accommodation and information, bringing together the growing community of nature seekers in Armenia.  Going Beyond Just Business-As-UsualDilijan Hikers Hostel will be more than just another small accommodation provider competing for bed sales. Directly bound to the success of our venture is the quality of the trail experience that helps make Dilijan a premier hiking destination, as well as the multi-faceted service industry that surrounds it.Our business model will both incorporate the local community through employment opportunities and support the organizations involved in rebuilding and maintaining Dilijan National Park's trail network. In other words, our success will be shared with everyone – with the goal of giving back as much as we get. Here's how:Local Employment Opportunities: Running our hostel will require hands-on help, from cleaning to cooking for larger groups, laundry service, and building maintenance. All the renovation work, materials purchased and furniture made will happen within the local community. Our guests will also help support local employment by booking transportation services, hiring local hiking guides, renting equipment, and more. Supporting Local Businesses: We want to help our guests experience everything unique that Dilijan has to offer. We'll work together with restaurants, museums, cafes, and other services offered throughout the town to make this happen. This combination of local culture and natural wonders is a key part of what makes a visit to Dilijan so memorable.Supporting Ecotourism & Conservation: From designing new trails to renovating and maintaining existing routes to keep them accessible and safe, a community of dedicated people and organisations continues to improve the trail experience for visitors of the park. We won't just be local advocates for their goals but give our guests the opportunity to support them – perhaps even volunteering to help – and making our hostel available as a headquarters for those involved with trail building and maintenance.  Among the many organizations whose enormous efforts we will continue to support, here are some of the most prominent:

The Transcaucasian Trail (TCT): The TCT is establishing a world-class long-distance hiking trail more than 3,000km in length, following the Greater and Lesser Caucasus Mountains and connecting roughly two dozen national parks and protected areas in the region, including Dilijan National Park. Visit https://transcaucasiantrail.org


HIKEArmenia: HIKEArmenia is a non-profit NGO developing hiking infrastructure in Armenia and sharing the country's trail potential with the world, and has supported the development of Dilijan National Park's trail network for several years. Visit https://hikearmenia.org


Trails for Change (TFC): Born around the campfire during a volunteer trail-building camp in Dilijan National Park, the mission of TFC is to design, build and maintain a network of trails that span all of Armenia. Visit https://www.trailsforchangengo.org

 Here's How Dilijan Hiker's Hostel Stands OutLocation: With our location being right in the heart of picturesque Old Dilijan, a traveler couldn’t ask for anything better. Access to trails is only footsteps away, as well as transportation to get you further into the park. Beyond getting outdoors, we urge you to experience a taste of Dilijan’s local culture through its restaurants, cafes, and markets – all within just a few minutes' walk.Knowledgeable Staff: The Dilijan Hikers Hostel team will be there to welcome you and help you get the most out of your experience. In addition to providing maps, sharing knowledge and advice, and helping you prepare for your time in Dilijan National Park, we’ll be there to recommend which trails you and your group will enjoy the most, no matter what your fitness or skill level.Clean and Safe Facilities: A safe and clean environment is our top priority – not just taking extra precautions during the Covid-19 pandemic but ensuring a well-maintained communal living environment at all times. Peace of mind for our visitors is of utmost importance and we’ll be working hard to demonstrate this. Supporting Local Trails: Dilijan Hikers Hostel will directly support the local trail network by hosting volunteer trail maintenance events, providing tools and facilities, and donating a portion of its profits back to the Transcaucasian Trail. We will be the first of many affiliated businesses that will help ensure the future of TCT. Promote Environmental Awareness: We want to be a part of maintaining the health of Dilijan’s ecosystem. Providing educational material to guests and highlighting the fragility of our surroundings will ensure that we all do our part in fostering a community of low-impact travelers. Having Fun! What’s better than coming back from a long hike, taking a hot shower, and opening a bottle of beer with new friends? The hostel will be designed from the ground up as a communal environment where guests can share experiences and make new and unforgettable memories.Why Build Dilijan Hikers Hostel Now?The year of 2020 will go down in history for turning people's plans upside down and inside out – but we've all learned to adapt! One of the effects is that we anticipate a much higher number of local travelers in 2021. As and when the pandemic draws to an end, we expect to see the international community coming back to Armenia as more and more people resume their travel plans. We will be taking all the necessary steps to ensure the safety of our guests, while at the same time nurturing our hostel's potential for the future.Alright, Let's Talk Money. Where Will The Funds Go?We are lucky enough to have been donated the use of an old townhouse in the heart of Dilijan which will be converted into a hostel – but it needs some work! With one big effort this spring, we’ll be able to outfit the building to the high standards of comfort, safety, and sanitation so often lacking in Armenia. This project will require a couple of major renovation projects, along with a lot of volunteer help, and of course the tools and materials for DIY projects and furnishings. We also want ensure we can pay our local staff a fair salary from Day One.Here’s a breakdown of what needs to happen between now and opening day:In a bit more detail:Reception & Information Area: We want guests of our hostel to have access to extensive information about the trail network and the local area so they feel their time in Dilijan has been well spent. A number of DIY projects will be involved in creating a communal reception and information area for this to happen.Outdoor Roofing: It sounds like a big job...and it is! A new roof over our terrace and entranceway is certainly something we'll be hiring local contractors to build, but when finished, will guarantee that our guests can enjoy cooking, dining and hanging out in the fresh mountain air – even when it's raining!Outdoor Kitchen & Dining: Hikers love being outdoors, and in the time of Covid-19 it's best for safety too. So we'll provide a full outdoor kitchen and BBQ area to both bring people together and keep everyone safe. Summer in Dilijan is best spent with mornings soaking up the sun, days out on the trail, and evenings by a campfire, and that's exactly what we'll provide.Security: Peace-of-mind is essential in any communal environment. So we'll be installing security cameras, building private lockers, and encolsing the property with a secure gate and fence. At the same time we'll create a keyless entry system for our guests.Pavements: You know what’s not fun after tramping through the dirt all day? More dirt. A hikers' hostel needs to be the clean end-point of a long day on the trails. We’ve redesigned the access routes to our hostel with this in mind, and now we need the funds to build it.Plumbing: After a day out on the trails, there’s nothing you’re looking more forward to than a hot shower – and nothing worse than it running cold when someone turns on the tap in the kitchen! We'll be redesigning the building's plumbing to make sure this doesn't happen, and that everyone has hot and cold water when and where they need it.Electrical Installation: Old buildings in Armenia have often been wired... well, questionably. At the same time, today's travelers often pack a huge array of power-hungry devices. So we'll be outfitting the building with a brand new electrical system – critical for safety, and with the convenience of our guests a top priority.Large Appliances: Especially on a multi-day hike, laundry is a critical service for any hiker stopping over in a town like Dilijan. We'll be procuring a new and efficient washing machine that's up to this arduous task, along with a separate drying machine for rainy days (and there are plenty of those in Dilijan!).Air Conditioning & Ventilation: As well as being essential for comfort in the summer months, good ventilation is critical for hygiene in any communal living space.Business Operations: There's also plenty to do behind-the-scenes, including creating a booking system, website development, advertising, overhead costs, and salaries for our local staff. The complete guest experience is vital to the success of this venture, and we want to make it smooth and effortless.Emergency Funds: This is a big project with lots of variables, and that means having a contingency fund for when things don't quite go to plan. We've built a buffer into our budget so we're confident in being able to weather any sudden storms during our critical first year of operations.Perks for DonorsDilijan Hikers Hostel thanks you ahead of time for the contributions you make. Despite the limitations of this past year, we are expecting a high number of local tourists and want to ensure they have a clean and comfortable place to seek shelter in. Our commitment to serving our local community will be the foundation for this ever-growing project and we invite you to be a part of our journey! Pre-Book Your Stay: Summer is around the corner and soon we'll be rushing outdoors and planning some fun trips. Here's your chance to book your stay at Dilijan Hikers Hostel ahead of time and have a guaranteed spot available for you when you arrive in Dilijan. Whether you're pre-booking one night or more, alone or with friends, this is a great opportunity to plan ahead, receive lots of add-ons and a special thank you from us. Sponsoring the Local Community: A core objective for creating Dilijan Hikers Hostel is giving back to the trail network that brings us our guests! We invite you to help us by sponsoring trail clean-up days, trail-building events, and inviting local hikers to join us in exploring Dilijan National Park. Your efforts won't go unnoticed and you can expect to receive a special thank you from us and everyone who benefitted from your donation.Merchandise: In addition to handwritten thank-you cards, We'll also be rewarding our donors with beautifully crafted maps of Dilijan National Park. Check them out here: https://cartisan.org/product/dilijan-national-p....There's other TCT and Dilijan National Park merchandise available too – something, we hope, for everyone.

story:
Hello my tea lovers!!!


My story began a few years back, when I worked in one of Aberdeen’s coffee chains. What I loved about the job then (and what’s driven me to this point now) was the fascinating array of people I had the pleasure of meeting on a daily basis. It was after many chats with my lovely customers that I realized just how much people love good tea, and the glaringly obvious lack of it in Aberdeen. It was at that point that I committed myself to fill that gap in the market and give the people what they really want. Move over coffee your time is over! 

And so the dream of running my own tea boutique, serving the best quality teas in town was born.

 


Last November I decided to take the leap, and with my love and knowledge of loose tea, I began supplying Aberdeen and Shire with the best blends I could get my hand on, sourced from all around Europe. It wasn’t easy, but thanks to continued support from the public, since trading my blends are being sold both online and within a number of establishments within the city, such as Peapod vintage shop and The Cat in the Window Cat Café. Our products also go down a storm in the pop up fairs we have taken part in to date… people just love tea!


                     


But the ultimate goal is to open Aberdeen's first Boutique Tea Shop, offering a range of 70 specialized loose tea blends for customers to choose from, as well as home bakes and tea accessories to take home for all those tea enthusiasts... If you didn’t love tea before you will after a visit to our boutique! I aim to create a unique warm and cosy place, open late in the evenings, full of flavors from freshly brewed teas and baked treats, a place full of candlelight and great atmosphere, where every guest will feel at home... sounds like heaven yes? Well you’re in luck because these plans are well and truly underway! BUT (There’s always a ‘but’)… I need your support to push our plans to the finish line and make this dream a reality.

                  

What we have in place:

· Start up funds in the bank

· 70 tea blends ready for sale

· tea accessories in place (Teapots, tea infusers, lovely mugs etc.)

· special water boilers for perfect water temperature purchased

· massive support from the closest friends and family

And most importantly

- I have the premises! 

The lease is all signed, its official. I have the perfect location for the Tea Shop; it’s on Castlegate at the top end of Union Street, very close to the heart of the city centre, and in neighbourhood with Vue Cinema and Pure Gym, ACT Aberdeen, Lemon Tree, two art galleries (Newave and Peacock Visual Arts) and many more attractions. I couldn’t imagine a better location for such a venture.

 

Soon after my excitement in securing the perfect premises died down, the reality set in on just how much work is required to bring it up to the level I need it to be at for the boutique. Now that I have the keys and can start the renovations, it’s apparent that the funds I have in place will not cover the refurbishment costs… I am so close to realizing my dream that I refuse to turn back now at the last hurdle! But this is why I’m asking for your help, so that I can finish the shop and be ready to open on 1st of December.

                       


What I Need & What You Get

To make it all happen for the scheduled launch date, we need an additional £5000 to finish the shop and make it perfect for your visit. This money will go directly on refurbishment costs and furnishings. Work has already begun and so being very restricted on time, the campaign is live for 20 days only.

If the prospect of Aberdeen’s first ever tea shop isn’t enough to entice you to support the cause alone, we have several fantastic money saving perks on offer in exchange for your contribution. These can be used from day one of the tea shop operating, which if all goes well with your help will be December this year! If I don't reach the goal of £5000 I cant even think about exactly what that would mean for the plans, but I believe in you and with your support we can make this happen!                                                                                                

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign on your social media accounts, it won’t cost you anything, but can help a lot. Please tell your family, friends and co-workers and encourage them to take part and support this project.


Can you help to make this happen?

story:
Help the Dominican and Haitian street children in the Dominican Republic.


                                       What is Christmas for all?

       Christmas for all is a community service event that started in 2013 in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. This event was started to bring awareness to the hardships of the street children living in the Capital and surrounding communities, with a focus around the Christmas holidays. My U.S based non-profit, haitianrelieforganization.org, and a local Dominican non-profit, fundacionads.org, and community volunteers coordinated to provide a Christmas meal, a Christmas gift, and entertainment for the children living on the streets.

                                           The events set for this year

     

                                                                 My Story

       My daughter, who was a senior at a university in New England, wanted to write a paper her senior year and asked me what the difference was growing up in Haiti vs the United States.  I responded by asking her how old she was when she witnessed her first homicide. She really didn't understand my response and asked if I was joking with her. I said that I was not!  I told her that I had witnessed two homicides by the time I was 6 year old. Two young boys, no older than 15 years old, were brutally attacked and beaten to death because they had stolen a loaf of bread from a local merchant. A steep price to pay for a meal.  And one does not easily forget events like this.  

                                               What would you do?

         I have four children and my youngest son is the same age as those two young boys that were killed. He has all the privileges that come with living in a nice community: great schools, access to extra-curricular activities, but also food on the table every night and a roof over his head.    What if the roles were reversed? What if my son did not have those opportunities? What if my son and our family had little access to food  and were constantly hungry? Would he be forced to do the same thing that those two boys did when they lost their lives? I believe that the answer is YES!  This is what drives me to make this happen!  This is the life of street kids living in the Dominican Republic.  

                                                   Tough Streets

           Imagine a place where circumstances and conditions are so poor that one meal a day feels like abundance. Imagine a place where a child dying is a normal everyday occurrence. A place where kids have to defend themselves and cannot clothe, educate or even feed themselves at times. Now the place we just had you imagine.. It exists. The place we are speaking of in the life of a street kid in the Dominican Republic.

             We are hoping that with your help we can give them hope thru your gifts, even momentarily.   When a street kid gets a present it lets them know someone cares about them and that can be life changing.  One present, one meal, one touch from humanity.  It's that simple!! Let's put a smile on their eager faces around the holidays!

                                   

                                                 Our first event

     The first event took place on Dec 19th 2013 in a small park known for its aggressiveness and homelessness in Santo Domingo. We purchased all the ingredients to prepare a gourmet meal for the kids. Our volunteers prepared the food at their homes and it was delivered to our event site. We also purchased drinks and all the necessary supplies needed to dress the tables in the park.  Once set up, we invited all of the Dominicans, Haitians and Dominican/Haitians living on the streets to enjoy a meal. It was an event that attracted over 30 kids. Most of them who attended were living in the park in the immediate area.

                                                       Second Event

     The second event took place on December 20th 2014. This happened in Plaza Guibia, which is also located in Santo Domingo downtown on the Malencon. Because of exposure and word of mouth, this event grew to over 120 and needed a lot more staffing and expense. A local church and dance troupe volunteered to serve and put on a dance routine to entertain the children.


On the 27th of December, we drove 150 toys two hours west of the capital to a small isolated community in the Province of Azua and held a  Christmas gifts sharing ceremony with 150 of the towns children.  We called this event:" A gift for a smile."

 

                

                                                          This Year

     This year we are preparing to re-double our efforts for a much larger event!  We have already started making arrangements to be in three separate parts  of the Country. On Dec. 19, we will be in downtown Santo Domingo serving close to 300 meals in Plaza Guibia on the Malencone. On Dec. 20th, my partner foundation and I will drive two hours north east to a small agricultural town in Hato Mayor, called Capote, and  will have a Christmas gift giving ceremony complete with Santa and distribute 150 toys to the local children.  On Dec. 27, we are driving two and a half hours west of the Capital to another isolated small town in the province of Azua and repeat the gift giving ceremony.   We are anticipating to purchase over 250 gifts and serve over 300 for this event. 

This will be impossible for me to do alone!! That's why I'm reaching out to like minded people to help me reach my goal!! 

                                              A little about us

     Christmas for All began long before this campaign. My name is Henri Heyne. I was Born in Haiti and have been a resident of Connecticut for the past 25 years. I have owned and operated many restaurants in the past thirty years and now find myself on a different journey. Long before this campaign began,  I have been running a non-profit for the past 11 years and have been doing charity work in Haiti and the Dominican Republic on a small scale. Every mission that I have done leaves me with an empty feeling knowing that the need is so great. How can I help reach more people? One of my limitations is that I have self funded all of my trips and expenses associated with my travels. This will be the first time that I will be reaching out to others for financial support. 

              

          Last year with the help of my three son's, the generosity of our community, and the participation of some of our local merchants, We  were able to collect almost 75 toys here in our town and bring them to the Christmas event. Another 75 toys I purchased at a big box store in the Dominican Republic at my own expense.

     This year will be different.  We will not be collecting toys here in the United States, but purchase them at a big box store in Santo Domingo.  Money collected will be better used locally, avoiding the packaging, cost of shipping and  problems with customs.

       

                                     What We Need & What You Get
We are seeking  to raise $6,000 U.S to fund these events in December.
The money will go towards buying 300 Christmas gifts, enough food for 300, utensils, drinks,  renting tables, chairs, sound system, paying for security and transportation for nineteen volunteers from the different locations and events.
I have seen the impact that these events have on every individual that has participated in the past, not only the volunteers, but also the children and young adults that were served at these events. This event is Life changing!

                      Check out some of our perks for participating. 

                                                      Ultimately

      Any additional money raised will go towards our long- term project in the building of the TainoSchool.org located  in southwest Dominican Republic.  This is a project that will identify the children with the greatest  needs and create an environment where they can thrive and build a real future.  I  have been working on this school for the past two years and hope to have funded by the middle of 2016.  

Visit the Taino School Page Here

        Would you like to collaborate and participate in  funding the TainoSchool project?

 Go to haitianrelieforganization.org to Donate or TainoSchool.org on FB. for more info.  

                                  The Impact

Many people are blessed enough to live the nice lives they deserve but sometimes we forget the conditions that others are having to endure.  Here are some sobering facts about the street kids:

  • More than a quarter – 27.6 percent – of families lives in poverty in Santo Domingo, according to government statistics.

  • The Dominican National Council for Children and Adolescents runs 58 centers and provides assistance to 18,800 children nationwide.

  • More than 13 percent of all Dominican children ages 10 to14 works to help support their families, according to a 2006 government report.

  • All of the children served by the Niños Del Camino shelter in Santa Domingo come from impoverished families and 77 percent have experienced domestic violence, according to 2009 data from the shelter.

  • The Niños Del Camino shelter helped many street kids in 2009. Of those, 60% were Dominicans, 30% were Haitians and the rest were Dominican-Haitians. Forty percent of them had been in the streets for four to 10 years, according to the 2009 Niños Del Camino annual report.

  •         The stateless in the Dominican Republic

  • “The majority (of street kids) come from families where their most basic needs are not covered,” the Stateless in the DR report states.  Some children turn to the streets to help support their families, returning home at night. Others never go back.  One Sixteen-year-old named Manuel Antonio Santos has lived on the streets since he was 7. He occasionally visits his family in Los Guandules, a neighborhood that he describes as an “aggressive place.”  As you can clearly see this is not a life, but the miracle is all of these kids are craving the tools, knowledge and resources to become better and find help for themselves and their families.  So I appeal to you to help them around the holidays and show them that someone cares. They have an immense amount of hope despite what some may call a hopeless situation. That is why I have created this campaign for the “Christmas for the Street Kids of DR.” 

  • Your donation will truly make a big difference for all of these kids around the Christmas Holidays. Not only do these children look forward to this event every year! but we think it will have a lasting impact for the rest of their lives. 

                             Risks & Challenges

 I believe that we have minimized our risk on this project because of our past  success in previous years.  Our team is in place, Our program is already in place, Our local partner, fundacionads.org has been working on logistics and establishing contact with all of our local suppliers and having security for the event.

Our only Challenge would be not to reach our goal of raising $6,000. In the event that we do not reach our fundraising goal? We will use whatever money raised and adjust the number of children that we may help.  


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to make a contribution? please help us spread the word about this campaign.

  • This has proven to be one of the hardest things I have ever done. I don't have a million friends to share this with. But, I have the Internet and wonderful people who want to see me succeed.
  • Weather or not you contribute financially, please use the share tools on this page. Tweeting, sharing on Facebook or any other venues you have at your disposal will greatly enhance our exposure and increase our chances to succeed.
  • For those of us who don't like making donations over the Internet, please feel free to contact me via email((hfheyne@hotmail.com)) and I will provide you with a mailing address to send your check or money order to. I will post your contribution on the campaign with your name and I will deliver whatever perk you would like.
  • We are hoping that this will be a cause that others will help support, continue to grow, be part of a greater good and make a real difference in the lives' of these children that have become invisible to the word.

  • If you wish to contact us:
  • Website: Haitianrelieforganization.org
  •  Facebook: Christmas for All
  •                        Tainoschool.org
  • email: haitianrelief@hotmail.com

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
Help the Dominican and Haitian street children in the Dominican Republic.

                                       What is Christmas for all? 
       Christmas for all is a community service event that started in 2013 in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. This event was started to bring awareness to the hardships of the street children living in the Capital and surrounding communities, with a focus around the Christmas holidays. My U.S based non-profit, haitianrelieforganization.org, and a local Dominican non-profit, fundacionads.org, and community volunteers coordinated to provide a Christmas meal, a Christmas gift, and entertainment for the children living on the streets.                                            The events set for this year                                                                      My Story
        My daughter, who was a senior at a university in New
England, wanted to write a paper her senior year and asked me what the difference was growing up in Haiti vs the United
States.  I responded by asking her how old she was when she witnessed her
first homicide. She really didn't understand my response and asked if I
was joking with her. I said that I was not!  I told her that
I had witnessed two homicides by the time I was 6 year old. Two young
boys, no older than 15 years old, were brutally attacked and beaten to death
because they had stolen a loaf of bread from a local merchant. A
steep price to pay for a meal.  And one does not easily forget events
like this.                                                  What would you do?         I have four children and my youngest son is the same age as those two young boys that were killed. He has all the privileges that come with living in a nice community: great schools, access to extra-curricular activities, but also food on the table every night and a roof over his head.    What if
the roles were reversed? What if my son did not have those opportunities? What if my son and our family had little access to
food  and were constantly hungry? Would he be forced to do the same
thing that those two boys did when they lost their lives? I believe that the
answer is YES!  This is what drives me to make this happen!  This is
the life of street kids living in the Dominican Republic.                                                     Tough Streets


           Imagine a place where circumstances and conditions are so poor that one meal
a day feels like abundance. Imagine a place where a child dying is a normal
everyday occurrence. A place where kids have to defend themselves and cannot
clothe, educate or even feed themselves at times. Now the place we just had you
imagine.. It exists. The place we are speaking of in the life of a street kid in the Dominican Republic.             We are hoping that with your help we can give them hope
thru your gifts, even momentarily.   When a street kid gets a present it
lets them know someone cares about them and that can be life changing. 
One present, one meal, one touch from humanity.  It's that simple!! Let's put a smile on their eager faces around the holidays! 
                                    
                                                 Our first event
     The first event took place on Dec 19th
2013 in a small park known for its aggressiveness and homelessness in Santo Domingo.
We purchased all the ingredients to prepare a gourmet meal for the kids. Our volunteers prepared the food at their homes and it was
delivered to our event site. We also purchased drinks and all the necessary
supplies needed to dress the tables in the park.  Once set up, we invited all of the Dominicans,
Haitians and Dominican/Haitians living on the streets to enjoy a meal. It was
an event that attracted over 30 kids. Most of them who attended were living in
the park in the immediate area.



                                                       Second Event
     The second event took place on
December 20th 2014. This happened in Plaza Guibia, which is also
located in Santo Domingo downtown on the Malencon. Because of exposure and word
of mouth, this event grew to over 120 and needed a lot more staffing and
expense. A local church and dance troupe volunteered to serve and put on a
dance routine to entertain the children.



On the 27th of December, we drove 150 toys two hours west of the capital to a small isolated community in the Province of Azua and held a  Christmas gifts sharing ceremony with 150 of the towns children.  We called this event:" A gift for a smile."
 
                 
                                                          This Year
     This year we are preparing to re-double
our efforts for a much larger event!  We have already started making arrangements to be in three separate parts  of the Country. On Dec. 19, we will be in downtown Santo Domingo serving close to 300 meals in Plaza Guibia on the Malencone. On Dec. 20th, my partner foundation and I will drive two hours north east to a small agricultural town in Hato Mayor, called Capote, and  will have a Christmas gift giving ceremony complete with Santa and distribute 150 toys to the local children.  On Dec. 27, we are driving two and a half hours west of the Capital to another isolated small town in the province of Azua and repeat the gift giving ceremony.   We are anticipating to purchase over 250 gifts and serve over 300 for this event. 
This will be impossible for me to do alone!! That's why I'm reaching out to like minded people to help me reach my goal!!  
                                              A little about us

     Christmas for All began long before this
campaign. My name is Henri Heyne. I was Born in Haiti and have been a resident of Connecticut for the past 25 years. I have owned and operated many restaurants in the past thirty years and now find myself on a different journey. Long before this campaign began,  I have been running a non-profit for the past 11 years and have been
doing charity work in Haiti and the Dominican Republic on a small scale. Every mission that I
have done leaves me with an empty feeling knowing that the need is so great. How can I help reach more people? One of my limitations is that I have
self funded all of my trips and expenses associated with my travels. This will
be the first time that I will be reaching out to others for financial
support.                         Last year with the help of my three son's, the generosity of our community, and the participation of some of our local merchants, We  were
able to collect almost 75 toys here in our town and bring them to the Christmas event.
Another 75 toys I purchased at a big box store in the Dominican Republic at
my own expense.      This year will be different.  We will not be collecting toys here in the United States, but purchase them at a big box store in Santo Domingo.  Money collected will be better used locally, avoiding the packaging, cost of shipping and  problems with customs. 
                                            What We Need & What You GetWe are seeking  to raise $6,000 U.S to fund these events in December. The money will go towards buying 300 Christmas gifts, enough food for 300, utensils, drinks,  renting tables, chairs, sound system, paying for security and transportation for nineteen volunteers from the different locations and events. 
I have seen the impact that these events have on every individual that has participated in the past, not only the volunteers, but also the children and young adults that were served at these events. This event is Life changing!

                      Check out some of our perks for participating.                                                        Ultimately
      Any additional money raised will go towards our long- term project in the building of the TainoSchool.org located  in southwest Dominican Republic.  This is a project that will identify the children with the greatest  needs and create an environment where they can thrive and build a real future.  I  have been working on this school for the past two years and hope to have funded by the middle of 2016.  

Visit the Taino School Page Here


        Would you like to collaborate and participate in  funding the TainoSchool project?
 Go to haitianrelieforganization.org to Donate or TainoSchool.org on FB. for more info.  
                                     The Impact

Many people are blessed enough to live the
nice lives they deserve but sometimes we forget the conditions that others are
having to endure.  Here are some sobering
facts about the street kids:

More than a quarter – 27.6
percent – of families lives in poverty in Santo Domingo, according to
government statistics.
The Dominican National
Council for Children and Adolescents runs 58 centers and provides assistance to
18,800 children nationwide.
More than 13 percent of all
Dominican children ages 10 to14 works to help support their families, according
to a 2006 government report.
All of the children served
by the Niños Del Camino shelter in Santa Domingo come from impoverished
families and 77 percent have experienced domestic violence, according to 2009
data from the shelter.
The Niños Del Camino
shelter helped many street kids in 2009. Of those, 60% were Dominicans, 30% were
Haitians and the rest were Dominican-Haitians. Forty percent of them had been in
the streets for four to 10 years, according to the 2009 Niños Del Camino annual
report.
        The stateless in the Dominican Republic



“The majority (of street kids) come from
families where their most basic needs are not covered,” the Stateless in the DR
report states.  Some children turn to the
streets to help support their families, returning home at night. Others never
go back.  One Sixteen-year-old named Manuel
Antonio Santos has lived on the streets since he was 7. He occasionally visits
his family in Los Guandules, a neighborhood that he describes as an “aggressive
place.”  As you can clearly see this is
not a life, but the miracle is all of these kids are craving the tools,
knowledge and resources to become better and find help for themselves and their
families.  So I appeal to you to help
them around the holidays and show them that someone cares. They have an immense
amount of hope despite what some may call a hopeless situation. That is why I have created this campaign for the
“Christmas for the Street Kids of DR.”  


Your donation will truly make a big difference for all of these kids around the Christmas Holidays. Not only do these children look forward to this event every year! but we think it will have a lasting impact for the rest of their lives. 

                                Risks & Challenges  I believe that we have minimized our risk on this project because of our past  success in previous years.  Our team is in place, Our program is already in place, Our local partner, fundacionads.org has been working on logistics and establishing contact with all of our local suppliers and having security for the event. Our only Challenge would be not to reach our goal of raising $6,000. In the event that we do not reach our fundraising goal? We will use whatever money raised and adjust the number of children that we may help.        Other Ways You Can Help If you are not able to make a contribution? please help us spread the word about this campaign.   This has proven to be one of the hardest things I have ever done. I don't have a million friends to share this with. But, I have the Internet and wonderful people who want to see me succeed. 

Weather or not you contribute financially, please use the share tools on this page. Tweeting, sharing on Facebook or any other venues you have at your disposal will greatly enhance our exposure and increase our chances to succeed. 
For those of us who don't like making donations over the Internet, please feel free to contact me via email((hfheyne@hotmail.com)) and I will provide you with a mailing address to send your check or money order to. I will post your contribution on the campaign with your name and I will deliver whatever perk you would like. 

We are hoping that this will be a cause that others will help support, continue to grow, be part of a greater good and make a real difference in the lives' of these children that have become invisible to the word. 

If you wish to contact us:
Website: Haitianrelieforganization.org
 Facebook: Christmas for All
                       Tainoschool.org

story:
I am Dr.Jihad Mahmoud Hasanain from Rafah .
I work at Abu Yousef Al Najjar Hospital , Rafah " on the South of Gaza city "
Istarted to support children in their shelters and to reach the out-of access children where they live in poor and unhealthy non sanitized conditions during summer 2014 war on Gaza 

                            " Dr.jihad during a night shift at the Hospital "


                  " Dr.Jihad at the Operation Room During the Last war on Gaza " 

 The  M.P.C.  aims to :

➢ Reach All unreached children

➢ Provide Medical Aid
➢ Give consultations and Awareness Campaigns
➢ Provide sanitary facilities
➢ Applying Screening for common diseases and proper long term management
➢ Insure healthy Dietary and Educational and health Access

After three Gaza Wars
Three Gaza wars (Dec2008, Nov2012, Jul2014) Brought Gaza life to hell, buildings down, no infrastructure, no clean water, no enough medical and health services.
The 8 yrs siege on Gaza and the unsupported government make about 400 hundred medical doctors unemployed even the governmental hospitals need more far than this number .

According to PCHR Statistics about the 50-day war 2014, 2191 Palestinians were killed and more than 527 of them were children, about 3306 children were wounded and had temporary or permanent disabilities.
According to the United Nations Relief and Work Agency (UNRWA), more than 300,000 Gazans had been sheltering in its schools on August19th 2014, and up to 500,000 people have been displaced by the conflict.
The UN estimates that more than 20,000 homes have been reduced to rubble or rendered uninhabitable and workers are racing to avert humanitarian crisis by fixing damaged water mains and power lines .

Out reach medical Services

The Out Reach medical services became necessary in Gaza to cover wide range of  children of borderlines areas, children  without  shelters, uninsured children  and children  with low socioeconomic backgrounds and to cover another group of low educated careless group.



Common Children Health problems In Gaza Strip most preschool and school age children complain of :

● Anemia and dietary efficiencies

● Infectious Diseases

● Hereditary Problems

● Mental health and psychiatric problems

Anemia Among Gazan Children

A cross-sectional study was conducted between May and September 2012. A total of 357 preschool children were selected using multistage sampling method from Jabalya refugee camp, El Remal urban area, and Al Qarara rural area. Anthropometric indicators for children were measured using the WHO guideline. Descriptive and multivariate analyses were conducted to determine the prevalence  and associated factors of anemia.
The overall prevalence of anemia was 59.7% among preschool children in the Gaza Strip, 46.5% and 13.5% of which are mild and moderate, respectively. Boys were more susceptible to this deficiency than girls. Hemoglobin level decreased in children living in poor households. Underweight children were more susceptible to anemia than normal weight children
Infectious Diseases

Of most common are gastrointestinal parasites among pre-school children in Gaza.

 A study of 679 stool specimens were collected from pre-school

children aged <10 months to 60 months attending Ard El-Insan Association

(Community primary health care center) in Gaza city. Stool specimens were

inspected by a direct smear microscopy and sedimentation techniques. The

study found that 16.6% of the studied children were infected with intestinal

parasites. Infection with Giardia lamblia showed the highest prevalence

(10.3%) among other parasites detected. Intestinal parasite prevalence was

higher among male children than females. All age groups were susceptible

for parasitic infection and no clear trend due to age.

Possible causes that infections are common :

● Overcrowded shelters and houses

● Water pollution

● Bad sanitary measures

Other common infections in Gazan Kids :

● Upper respiratory infections, Otitis Media

● All types of Gastroenteritis

● Meningitis

Hereditary Problems :


Hereditary and congenital problems are of the highest rates

among the world here in Gaza, this mainly because of :

● Traditions of relatives marriage

● Early marriage (sometimes children marriage)

● Chemical effects of war weapons

● Lack of genetic consultation and advisory campaigns.


Why Children ?

The Out Reach medical services could serve every one, but more than 65% percent of Gazan population are younger than 15 yrs (2009), this implies that children compose the whole society and its future, thus serving children is the most necessary and required.


Mobile Pediatric Clinic  " M.P.C "

"The  Project Is not the first worldwide.. but it is most needed in Gaza "

It is Endless Project. It is estimated to help 5000 children every month.
It is planned to continue working as funds there and always our volunteers are enthused .
Mobile clinic will help more than 60,000 within the first  year only .
Our team has a predetermined rural and nomadic areas including many borderline areas and of most the Marginalized areas. Most of these areas in :

1)North Gaza

2)Middle Camps

3) Almawasee (between Rafah and Khanyounis)

4) Southern Rural areas

Required instructional fund is calculated to cover :

(1) 4-6 meters long van and turning it to a clinic with all requirements ..  need :  (50.000 $)
(2) Medical instruments including Stethoscopes,Otoscopes, Torches and hammers, Mazhurhs, Fundoscopes, oxymeters,Glucometers, samples Sphegmanometer, Thermometers in addition to tow laptops :
 need (4200$) 
Details :
The 4-6  meters long van will include a clinic " room  and a small ICU unit with an oxygen Supply, monitor, DC Defibrillator, and most of ICU instruments, but not a ventilator, it will include a call-machine that we could access Red Crescent and Emergency service anytime anywhere.

 

 

 " these photos are  an Examples  for the bus we planned to use as a clinic "

 (3) Required operational fund is calculated to cover (2000 $) monthly :

● Disposables, Fuel

● Labs

● Sanitary tools

● Volunteers' gifts

● Driver's salary

● Medication " we make agreement with four  pharmacies  that will provide the needed Drugs with  a cheapest price "

The Project is planned to give each individual child a file that he could follow up and re-seek our help anytime later easily.
It would be an electronic recording system .

Timeline

The 4-6 meters long van will put its wheels and go on the 1st of July 2016
 if all things going OK as planned .
● Then our work will be on monthly basis , every month we will visit 10 areas,  each 2 days, with a full-day work.

"Lack of donation /
 is the only thing that will prevent continuing this project "

WE NEED The sum of 54.200 USD to make this supreme project helping Gazan children come true, another monthly 2000  USD are required to continue our endless project ( and this will be available as we will provide a semi-free medical services as  the patient will pay 2-4 $ to get the services and for children who don't have money to pay .we will provide the services with free charge )" the project made for them basically "

In planning ,The project are going to have days of work ..
every day in different area with different children. each work-day will have a name and well be celebrated and covered on media.

●Each Donor who donates Above 1000 USD will have a work-day with his own name. Pictures and reports of that day well be sent to him.

If we failed to collect 54.200USDbefore April 2016 ,then we have some other plans :
1)Minimizing project costs with decreasing effectiveness

2)We have other plans in help improving children health

3)We will call back donors to ask them for using their money in other projects or returning it back

f you consider any assistance or ask for more details please refer to my accounts on Facebook DrJihad M. Hasanain or you can send me message via
 e-mail : dr.jihad90@gmail.com

You can help me by Donating to this online fundraising campaign and share the link widely with your friends, family and everyone who can contribute.
also you can help by spreading the Hashtags of #Mobile_Pediatric_Clinic  on social media with link of this campaign .

WE NEED The sum of 54.200 USD to make this supreme
project helping Gazan children come true, another monthly 2000  USD are required to
continue our endless project ( and this will be available as we will provide a semi-free medical services as  the patient will pay 2-4 $ to get the services and for children who
don't have money to pay .we will provide the services with free charge )" the
project made for them basically "
In planning
,The project are going to have days of work ..every day in different area with
different children. each work-day will have a name and well be celebrated and
covered on media.
●Each Donor who donates Above
1000 USD will have a work-day with his own name. Pictures and reports of that
day well be sent to him.
If we failed
to collect 54.200USDbefore April 2016 ,then we
have some other plans :1)Minimizing project costs with decreasing effectiveness
2)We have other plans in help improving children health
3)We will call back donors to ask them for using their money in
other projects or returning it backf you consider any assistance or ask for more details please refer to my accounts on Facebook DrJihad M. Hasanain or you can send me message via e-mail : dr.jihad90@gmail.comYou can help me by Donating to this online fundraising campaign and share the link widely with your friends, family and everyone who can contribute.also you can help by spreading the Hashtags of #Mobile_Pediatric_Clinic  on social media with link of this campaign .

story:
Rosegold: English rose meets golden California

Rosegold is a sharing-style restaurant with an internationally influenced menu. Fresh ingredients will be seasonal and as locally sourced as possible, and drinks will include wines from California, France, Italy and Spain, coffee imported from California, and beer from Mexico.
Venues in London try to be moody and edgy, when let's face it, London does a pretty good job of that on its own given our serious lack of sunshine. The atmosphere at Rosegold will be bright and inviting, but elegant with a California-inspired interior design. What I'm most excited about, is striving to serve every guest with a focus on elevated hospitality. Let's kickstart a hospitality revolution with higher standards of service, making guests feel as if they've enjoyed an evening at a great friend's dinner party - without that obligatory offer to help clean up!


Hello! I'm Alessandra. I'm a California girl that left the sunshine and sand of Southern California for a life in London. Why on earth would I do that? Because London is the best city in the world! Alright, you may not necessarily agree, but it is the centre of an incredible amount of exciting opportunities, both business and otherwise. Having helped launch restaurants, worked on their PR development, devised marketing and social media strategies, been a food critic, and most importantly, performed an excessive amount of edible research, I plan on taking my diverse background in the food industry and passion for hospitality to open and run Rosegold. This will be the first in my international empire of restaurants, each bespoke in their concept, with a focus on fantastic food and impeccable hospitality. 


What We Need: £100,000

Although this is only a portion of what I'll need for a project as great as this, you will be helping me maintain a stake in the business by covering some crucial start-up costs. Essentially - you're helping me buy parts of the restaurant!

Let me break it down for you:
Video - this awesome thing you've just watched: £1,200            
Website & Branding: £6,000
PR & Marketing: £9,000
Legal Fees: £10,000
Permits & Licenses: £4,000
Insurance: £5,000
Restaurant EPOS System: £1,200
Ordering and Payment Machines: £600
Glassware, Crockery & Cutlery: £15,000
Menus & Printed Materials: £2,000 
Linens, Napkins & Uniforms: £700
Tables & Chairs: £17,500
Combi Ovens & Ranges: £6,000
Coffee Machine: £1,500 
Sous Vide Machine: £300
Convection Ovens: £360
Kitchen Aid: £450
Frying Unit: £230
Sinks: £1,160
Pots & Pans: £2,000
Walk-In Refrigerator: £5,500
Commercial Freezer: £1,000
Gas Oven & Grill: £3,000
Ice Cream Maker: £300
Dishwashers: £2,000 
Tools & Utensils: £3,000
Stainless Steel Kitchen Hood Extraction: £1,000

What You Get:

Since you're helping with some essential start-up costs and buying pieces of the restaurant - we'd love to give you a piece of Rosegold in return, and are offering some incredible experiences. From Rosegold gear you can wear to represent the brand - to VIP Rosegold Cards - to customised dinner parties, you better get in quick with some of these awesome perks before the campaign closes! Please note that no alcohol is included in any of the offerings - sorry, their rule, not mine.
Also, please feel free to donate above the denoted value! :) 

Risks & Challenges

The endless advice, warnings and words from friends, family, restaurateurs, chefs and advisors have all cautioned me to the extreme risk involved in the restaurant industry. But, my career and success as a restaurateur is not an "IF", but a "WHEN". The only way to absolutely ensure failure, is to never have tried in the first place! 

When opening a restaurant, you must successfully address your target market, cast a wide net with marketing and PR, develop a happy customer base, train and grow your team to work towards achieving the same goal, and constantly adapt to change and circumstance. I want Rosegold to be a stable addition to the food scene, not a short-lived hotspot to ride out a temporary trend wave. I have built a network of professionals, advisors and industry-based contacts to both consult with and advise against stumbling at any obvious hurdles. Besides that, my insurmountable passion will help me overcome any glance at failure, as I will only ever learn from experiences of what to avoid at my next attempt. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You or someone you know are interested in being a major investor, and would like to take a look at the business plan and financial projections?
Contact me at rosegoldrestaurant@gmail.com

You can't afford to contribute, but still believe in Operation Rosegold?
PLEASE SHARE WITH ANYONE AND EVERYONE YOU KNOW!
You never know who would be willing to contribute, and they'll receive some great perks in return.
Thank you - and I can't wait to welcome you to Rosegold!

Contact me at rosegoldrestaurant@gmail.com You can't afford to contribute, but still believe in Operation Rosegold? PLEASE SHARE WITH ANYONE AND EVERYONE YOU KNOW! You never know who would be willing to contribute, and they'll receive some great perks in return. Thank you - and I can't wait to welcome you to Rosegold!

story:
Hi! I'm Jeanette, 

Thanks so much for visiting our crowdfunding campaign. 

I'm one of the owners of Soup 'n Such, and I'm on here to ask for your help in expanding our business to help us serve you better.

  • Soup 'n Such is located at 2285 Dundas W, just south of where Dundas & Bloor meet. It neighbours the Junction, Roncesvalles & High Park. 

  • We serve fresh, homemade, nutritious food made from scratch in our tiny, 1 person kitchen 

  • Nut-free, gluten-free, dairy-free, worry free! We specialize in food restrictions of all kinds including dishes for vegans & vegetarians. 

(including baked goods!) 


What We Need & What You Get

Our Wish List (In order of priority)
  • A New Conventional Stove (with 4 burners!) Currently we're operating with only 2 working burners... and cooking 5 soups. 
  • Expand Staff - Having a prep cook and additional part-timer will allow us to be able to open Sundays, begin offering delivery, and expand our catering service
  • (BONUS) Espresso Machine - If we are fortunate enough to take care of the basics... we'd love to purchase an espresso machine. This one's really for our customers <3 
Financial Targets (and cost breakdown)
$5,000 - will cover the cost of the new stove & installation
$10,000 - stove + staff expansion 
$15,000 - stove + staff expansion + espresso machine
$20,000 -  stove + staff expansion + espresso machine + needed renos 
* we've prioritized financing so the projects that need it the most get it first and ensured your perk delivery will not be affected regardless of our result.
Now the fun part... 
What's In It For You!

Everything from naming your own Sandwich... to feeding the homeless - and getting bottomless coffee months at a time - there truly is something for everybody. 

Check out our perks to see what tickles your fancy!

As we climb the funding ranks... we'll add fun new perks (like the Thanks a Latté card)  ;)


The Impact

We’re already making great food at affordable prices but keeping our margins low means certain goals are currently out of our reach. Through this campaign we hope to raise enough funds to allow us to drastically improve the service for existing customers by opening Sundays and offering delivery with the purchase of a new stove and the initial bump needed to hire a couple part timers to handle the increased volume. 

We offer real food at prices that are comparable to fast food chains that are heavy on processed ingredients. 


Risks & Challenges

I have 37 years experience in the food industry and run several restaurants before opening Soup 'n Such. The most profitable restaurants cut corners on ingredients to profit at your expense while charging a premium for it. I’m committed to providing home cooked meals made with real food at a price anyone can justify so they can choose a healthy, delicious option and actually enjoy it!
My goal with this café was never to be rich but money is still required to add a few things that will benefit everyone that appreciates what we’re doing. 
We’re asking existing customers to vote with their dollars if they want to see these changes in our café and new customers to consider contributing in exchange for great perks that will save them money off our normal menu prices. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • The best way to help is to come in and see us! We love serving the community fresh, healthy food and the more you eat, the more we can grow.
  • You can also help us spread the word! Tell your friends in the neighbourhood, share it around online! 
  • Share using the buttons below :D 

Oh wait! Before you go....

Our little rescue Sunshine says thank you so much for stopping by <3
